docs.snippet: Sugar Shane Mosley may have jumped two weight classes, going from lightweight (135 pounds) to welterweight (147 pounds), but he has not lost any of his confidence.    ''I predict I will look spectacular in my fight on Saturday night,'' Mosley said...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sugar Shane Mosley may have jumped two weight classes, going from lightweight (135 pounds) to welterweight (147 pounds), but he has not lost any of his confidence. ''I predict I will look spectacular in my fight on Saturday night,'' Mosley said.
docs.abstract: Article on Sugar Shane Mosley in view of upcoming welterweight bout against Willy Wise in Las Vegas (M)

headline.main: Mosley Likes Chances In Higher Weight Class

docs.snippet: Theater    ''THE CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS.'' The Bronx Arts Ensemble and the New York Lyric Circus present Saint-Saens's musical piece about a lively crew of creatures, which will include not only human musicians and mimes but also two canine perfo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Theater ''THE CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS.'' The Bronx Arts Ensemble and the New York Lyric Circus present Saint-Saens's musical piece about a lively crew of creatures, which will include not only human musicians and mimes but also two canine performers: Cobweb and Luciano, Maltese dogs that specialize in jumping through hoops and dancing on their hind legs. Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Riverdale YM-YWHA, 5625 Arlington Avenue, at West 256th Street, the Bronx. To reach the Y from Manhattan, ride the IRT No. 1 or No. 9 to 231st Street, then take No. 7 or No. 10 bus to Riverdale. Tickets: $7. Reservations: (718) 601-7399.

docs.snippet: The immanence of guilt and the fallibility of mankind overarch the knotted racial relations of South Africa in the provocative, mysterious thriller ''Quarry.''    Its title alone, suggesting either a place where building blocks are excavated or pr...
docs.lead_paragraph: The immanence of guilt and the fallibility of mankind overarch the knotted racial relations of South Africa in the provocative, mysterious thriller ''Quarry.'' Its title alone, suggesting either a place where building blocks are excavated or prey that is hunted, bears witness to the intriguing ambiguity that characterizes an excellent film willing to grapple with daunting human and political complexities.
docs.abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder reviews Marion Hansel's film The Quarry, starring John Lynch; photo (M)

headline.main: Stolen Life, Stolen Car, Stolen Soul

docs.snippet: The Clinton administration issued visas on Thursday to the grandmothers of 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez, a move that would allow the two women to travel to the United States from Cuba and that could set up a custody showdown on American soil between ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton administration issued visas on Thursday to the grandmothers of 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez, a move that would allow the two women to travel to the United States from Cuba and that could set up a custody showdown on American soil between two sets of the Cuban boy's relatives. The American diplomatic mission in Havana granted the visas as a delegation from the National Council of Churches, which has sought the return of the boy to his father in Cuba, landed in Havana Thursday night and met with the women.
docs.abstract: Clinton administration issues visas to grandmothers of 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez, move that would allow two women to travel to United States from Cuba and that could set up a custody showdown on American soil between two sets of boy's relatives; American diplomatic mission in Havana grants visas as delegation from National Council of Churches, which has sought return of boy to his father in Cuba, lands in Havana and meets with women (M)

headline.main: Cuban Boy's Grandmothers Hoping to Fly to U.S.

byline.original: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. with DAVID GONZALEZ

docs.snippet: In the Running For an Oscar      The meeting took place in the cafe of the Four Seasons Hotel in Beverly Hills, the power breakfast site of choice. Mike Leigh (left), director of ''Topsy-Turvy,'' a love sonnet to the theater in the form of a biogr...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the Running For an Oscar The meeting took place in the cafe of the Four Seasons Hotel in Beverly Hills, the power breakfast site of choice. Mike Leigh (left), director of ''Topsy-Turvy,'' a love sonnet to the theater in the form of a biography of Gilbert and Sullivan, waved across the room to Anthony Minghella, director of ''The Talented Mr. Ripley,'' the lavish adaptation of the Patricia Highsmith novel about a chameleonlike serial killer.
docs.abstract: At the Movies column; director Mike Leigh discusses Oscar outlook for his film Topsy-Turvy; James C Katz comments on restoring classic film Rear Window, now back in lush color; Landmark Theaters, nation's largest chain of art-house cinemas, marks 25th anniversary with poll of audience favorites; Life is Beautiful is in first place; Jay Russell discusses his film My Dog Skip, from memoir by late writer Willie Morris; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Antiques on Park 69th Regiment Armory, 26th Street at Lexington Avenue; (212) 255-0020. One hundred dealers will participate in a show and sale of antique furniture, ceramic vases, prints, lamps, textiles, silver tableware and garden objects tomorrow and Saturday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m., and Sunday to 5. Admission is $10.

headline.main: Art, Antiques and Attire To See and Hear About

docs.snippet: Gene Harris, a jazz pianist who plied a polished, mainstream and agreeably bright brand of blues, soul and bebop, died on Sunday at his home in Boise, Idaho. He was 66.    The cause was complications from kidney failure a month before he was expec...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gene Harris, a jazz pianist who plied a polished, mainstream and agreeably bright brand of blues, soul and bebop, died on Sunday at his home in Boise, Idaho. He was 66. The cause was complications from kidney failure a month before he was expecting a kidney transplant from one of his daughters, The Associated Press said.
docs.abstract: Gene Harris, jazz pianist, dies at age 66; photo (M)

headline.main: Gene Harris, 66, a Jazz Pianist Who Played Bebop and Soul

docs.snippet: Prof. Bruce Gans was wildly pacing the front of classroom A-307, dashing from Yeats's ''Second Coming'' to Keats's ''Ode to a Nightingale,'' with brisk detours through the Bible, T. S. Eliot, Nietzsche and Arthur Miller.    The setting for this me...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prof. Bruce Gans was wildly pacing the front of classroom A-307, dashing from Yeats's ''Second Coming'' to Keats's ''Ode to a Nightingale,'' with brisk detours through the Bible, T. S. Eliot, Nietzsche and Arthur Miller. The setting for this meditation on the great works of Western civilization was not Oxford or Harvard or the University of Chicago. It was a night class at Wilbur Wright College, a community college on this city's North Side that caters to high school graduates considered not ready for four-year institutions, as well as to X-ray technicians, cellular phone sales clerks and bank tellers looking to better their lot.
docs.abstract: Western classics, long dismissed by critics as celebrating works of extinct and almost exclusively white male writers, are making comeback at number of institutions nationwide, many in unexpected places; institutions, most ranked in middle to lower end of acedemic pack, are taking steps to underline study of classics and emphasize importance in liberal arts education in ways that recall pioneering 'great books programs' at University of Chicago and Columbia University in early 20th century; deans at institutions involved say addition over past 10 years of minors in women's studies, African-American studies and gay and lesbian issues has opened window for those who feel classical canon should get due; almost all new programs have been started on shoestring by people who believe such courses have been diluted in name of political correctness; course taught by Prof Bruce Gans at Wilbur Wright College in Chicago described; photo (M)

headline.main: After Bitter Campus Battles, The 'Great Books' Rise Again

docs.snippet: Dr. Harold E. Edgerton was a wizard of invention who changed the way people see things. The flash of his camera opened up hidden worlds of motion: of golf clubs flattening apparently rigid balls, of drops of milk forming crowns of splattered dropl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Harold E. Edgerton was a wizard of invention who changed the way people see things. The flash of his camera opened up hidden worlds of motion: of golf clubs flattening apparently rigid balls, of drops of milk forming crowns of splattered droplets, of beetles firing seemingly fluid secretions in what turned out to be rapid pulses. His photographs revealed the drama hidden in the commonplace. A born showman, Dr. Edgerton communicated his love of science and discovery to students and peers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he worked and taught for more than six decades.
docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Harold E Edgerton, pioneer of stop-action photography (S)

headline.main: The Man Who Stopped Time and Opened Worlds
